COURSE DESCRIPTION: This course has several goals: (1) to introduce students to readings on a wide variety of themes; (2) to teach students how to think critically about the issues addressed in the readings; (3) to discuss, in English, the issues addressed in the readings; (4) to help students become familiar with new vocabulary and how it is used in the readings; and (5) to prepare students to be able to paraphrase passages from the readings and answer essay questions related to the readings.  
  
ORGANIZATION OF THE COURSE: One to three class sessions will be devoted to each reading. There will be some lecturing, but this will be minimal. The course is conducted primarily through discussion. The main ideas the author is trying to express, whether readers would agree or disagree with the author, culture points, vocabulary, and grammar will all be addressed.

Materials:  
**Textbook**: Goldthwaite, Melissa, Bizup, Joseph, Fernald, Anne, and Brereton, John. (2020). _The Norton Reader_. _(Shorter Fifteenth Edition)._ Upper Saddle River, New York: W. W. Norton & Company.
